channel.title: Grandparent stories
channel.description:
Our beloved grandparents always have some fantastic stories to tell and I was talking to the sole remaining grandfather I have today. He was telling me about this one fond memory he had of my grandmother and I found it sort of funny. if you have any fond stories you wish to share feel free to as well.
Emmie Nichols was in the living room knitting with her mother when her father came in and asked for her and her eldest brother to fetch the bottles from the woodshed. Now, not many people knew this, but Mr. Nichols was a moonshiner. He did it as more of a general hobby then as a business. It was a tradition that was brought down from generation to generation as a Nichols. So off the two children went to the woods. On the way back, with bottles and all in their wooden holsters they were walking back up the path when the county sheriff and his faithful deputy pulled to the side of the road. Now the Nichols lived in a small one story house with only four rooms. The house lived on the corner of a road so the police stopped their car on the side of the house and saw the two children walked towards the house wielding wooden boxes with something in them. The sheriff walked over to the two children while heading to the house. He smiled at the children and tipped his hat in greeting. "Mornin' Emmie, your pa at home." "Yes sir Mr. Barnes. He's be in the living room with Ma." "Thank you Emmi...what you be holding there gal?" "Oh this be my pa's moonshine Mr. Barnes sir. Pa asked me to take it to him for tonight deliveries." "Did he now? Well have a nice day little Emmie."
Long story short, my great granddad got ratted on by my grandmother for moonshining without even knowing it back in the 1940's. From what I was also told he never did really forgive her for that as he spent several years in jail for it.

item.title: Grandparent stories
item.dc:creator: @krackkid Krackkid
item.description:
@krackkid wrote:

[quote=“Loveandpower, post:16, topic:465830”][quote author=Krackkid link=topic=572450.msg4139268#msg4139268 date=1351985732]
I went over to my grandparents house for lunch one day, Just road over there and sat down at the table and he was like “Chris you wanna know something about when I was younger” I was of course wanting to know this he was like “Normally in my day if someone came uninvited for lunch we would serve them the food and welcome them open heart to the house” I was like oh cool thanks then he was like “But since its not when I was a kid go take your stupid ass back out side and tell you mom she can feed you!” he hurt my feelings.
[/quote]now that’s funny and sounds like something an old guy would say[/quote]Its true he was joking though so it made it less funny xD

Read full topic

item.title: Grandparent stories
item.dc:creator: @F_A_I_L_S Fails
item.description:
@F_A_I_L_S wrote:

My grandma was telling me a story not to long ago about my grandfather. (He passed away when I was 3) Anyway, he used to work in a paper-mill, and one day he came across 650$ on the ground. Of course he did the right thing and tried to find out who it belonged to, assuming it was someone he worked with. Well, it turned out it was his bosses money and he got a promotion.

Was this story interesting? No. I don’t have any outstanding stories to share, although I wish I did. I have a pretty boring family.

Read full topic

item.title: Grandparent stories
item.dc:creator: @vManlyMan vManlyMan
item.description:
@vManlyMan wrote:

My mom and Grandma were telling me a story about something that happened to us a long time ago. We were going to get something for my cousins birthday party, (it was late at night), and the store we were going to was about to close. We went in the first doors, then they locked and the ones in front of us locked so we were stuck in the entrance to this store all night long. At one point, there was a janitor on one of the floor waxers that you drive in, but he had ear buds in so he couldn’t hear everyone screaming at him to open the doors. I was too young to remember it, but it was pretty funny when they were telling it to me.

Read full topic

item.title: Grandparent stories
item.dc:creator: @Loveandpower Loveandpower
item.description:
@Loveandpower wrote:

[quote=“Rodgerwilco, post:4, topic:465830”]My grandfather told me a story about his dad/my great grand daddy. Anyways… I guess he was wanted by the cops or something. The cops broke into the house and he threw my grandfather into the closet and shot 4 cops. Packed up their belongings and moved to California.

Dunno if its real, probably not. No idea tbh, wouldn’t know where to start looking… but yea. I also asked my grandpa how much ass he got back in the day and he told me his number was 9. likeaboss.[/quote]yeah they do stretch the truth occasionally to keep their grand babies interested

Read full topic

item.title: Grandparent stories
item.dc:creator: @Loveandpower Loveandpower
item.description:
@Loveandpower wrote:

[quote=“Ruby, post:2, topic:465830”]This one time when my granddad worked for a removals company him and his friends went on a panty-raid and tied all the womans pants together and hanged them from each window in the house.

That was probably one of the best stories he’s ever told me.[/quote]haha now that does sound like something old people would do. Nobody would have the gall to do that in today’s world xD

Read full topic
